ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because of COVID, we did not get to have any in-person labs. In a normal year it would be a great chance to get good hands-on experience in a ChemE lab, but this year we simply were given the data to do analysis with for our reports. The main skill gained this year was practice writing good reports, summarizing data, and identifying sources of error.

I learned many useful excel skills and the ability to sift through lots of data to make sense of it. Also, I learned some more on experimental membrane separating, distillation, reactor use, heat transfer, and complex fluids.

Most of the course focused on the bigger picture analysis of the labs rather than detailed correlations of data. I found that very useful especially since nowadays, those correlations are easily done on a computer and I think this course did a great job in training us to think about what the data actually means and what factors are influencing the data.
I learned about important ChemE techniques (from lectures), how to analyze data, and how to write lab reports.
I developed the ability to work quickly and efficiently with a team when presented with theory and mass amounts of data. Error analysis, etc.

It was just building upon the chemical engineering foundation we already had from all our other classes. The difference was we got to see it in action vs in theory, so it felt a lot more real through this class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the strengths of this course are the fact that you work together on every lab in a group of three. Also, I think having one TA per group greatly helped with answering any questions we had in a timely manner. I think a major weakness is that we could not physically conduct any of the labs in person which greatly hindered our real world skills with this equipment.

Unfortunately, being a lab class, the virtual experience was not ideal. However, I think the lab group meetings after lecture were great for collaboration and problem solving between the team and it was great to have a TA there to help out through the difficult parts of the analysis.

The variety of lab techniques reviewed was a plus, but I felt that there was little guidance on how to write a lab report.  I think a more thorough explanation at the beginning of the course would have been helpful.

The fact that the course was a laboratory course conducted virtually was very difficult. Though this isnt a fault of the course itself as much as it is the fault of the circumstances, it made the data analysis portion difficult. Professor and TA availability is a strength.

I mean the structure of the class is very good, two weeks to do a lab and then two weeks after that to do a lab report. I wish the expectations of the lab reports were made a little clearer earlier on, or like an example report was provided for us. That would have been very helpful. Also having a lot of TAs was very beneficial and a strength for sure.

Although I don't feel like I can accurately do this question justice being I had a virtual experience.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The work with breakout groups worked decently well. Class was 3 hours, 2.5 hours of which was working with your group to complete data analysis and .5 hours of which was a lecture from the professor. I think the lectures could have been longer to provide us with more background knowledge and instructions before we began actually working on the labs.
I think that splitting up into breakout rooms for each group succeeded and allowed for easy communication at a set time.

The lab videos where the TA's explained the lab setup were often critical to my understanding of the lab. Having at least a visual of the equipment used really helped me make more sense of the data we were presented and how we might use it.
Hopefully this class does not have to be virtual again, as it's a lab class that benefits greatly from having students actually perform experiments.

Maybe incorporating simulations for some labs (an example that could illustrate this is sapling learnings use of titration simulations to encourage student engagement and learning) could help understanding of the theory behind the labs. Group assignments was very effective

Recorded lectures helped, using breakout rooms was good. I wish there was more use of the canvas page, as it has a lot of functionality meant to help both students and faculty alike, but it was almost never used. I am thinking specifically of the assignments tab, all our lab reports were handed in via email which is fine, but can definitely feel wishywashy at times as emails can get lost in an inbox all the time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Would only recommend to those who are in the ChemE ABET major, for which it is a requirement.

I would not recommend this course to anyone other than ABET ChemEs and anyone who thoroughly enjoys adding to their lab skills. Other than that, I do not see the practical purpose in taking a time intensive course that you would have no use for beyond ChemE.
This class did have a lot more writing than I was expecting. It was a welcome change of pace from exams but just be prepared for it

If you're planning on taking this course, you're a ChemE ABET track senior who is pretty close to being done.  This course is a bit of work, but the big benefit is that the class is finished before reading period starts - great way to end senior year.

Highly recommend, Dr. Pfefferle is very direct and helpful when engaging with students and helps learning a lot. Same with the TAs; they make their availabilities known to students and are quite responsive when students require extra help
If you have the chemical engineering background and want to see what it's like applied to the real world, then yes.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met once at the end of the semester for a class, but other than that all virtual.
Recorded lectures were very helpful in reviewing material for the lab reports

There was a virtual 30 minute lecture to begin the lab followed by a session in a separate Zoom room with the rest of your lab group (2-3 other students) and a TA.  This separate Zoom room was designed for the lab group to work together to analyze the data collected from previous years' experiments.
Group efforts outside of class via zoom
It was a mix of live virtual lecture and virtual seminar with our lab groups
